div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,132] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are intended to leave port Said on or about the following dates:
Port Said to London Via Brindisi
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from Port Said to London via Brindiri or via Marseilles £25.9.11.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China eery alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Caloutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was a summer's day in the early part, but at 1p.m. the wind suddenly veered to the N.E. giving every appearance of rain and squally weather. Shortly after, however, it backed again to the westward in shower of rain, and by 9p.m. a dead calm prevailed. There was a clear sky and the night was beautiful. Barometer high and rising.

div.head: THE NILE
div.p: We have already alluded to the recent observations of Sir William Preece relative to the neglected condition of the Nile, but both by reason of the importance of the topic discussed, no less than on account of the professional position of the lecturer, it deserves fuller consideratino, as it possesses for dwellers in Eygpt an absorbing interest. The Nile is the most precious gift bestowed by a bounteous Providence upon this favored land, and every means which practical science can suggest should be employed to utilise to the fullest possible extent the purposes it is intended to serve. The P.W.D. has, up to the present, been regarded by common consent as comprising a body of highly trained and experienced experts of which any country might be proud, and upon whose judgment the public has been in the habit of placing absolute and unquestioning reliance. To the initiative and capacity of this department we owe the conception and accomplishment of one of the grandest engineering feats which the modern world has witnessed. But it may reasonably be asked whether the preservation of the river's depth at its normal and requisite level, the maintenance of its banks in an efficient state of repair, and the counteracting of its dangerous and impeding currents between Assouan and Alexandria, is not a duty which, though far more modest and less imposing than the erection of dams and reservoirs, is equally essential of fulfilment Can it be that we have been sleeping the sleep of the seven sleepers all this while, only to be rudely awakened by the clarion tones of Sir William's perturbing though timely warning? Has the idol that we have so long venerated nothing but feet of clay, which his well-directed blows have shattered to atoms? Englishmen, to whatever class they belong, are, as a rule, slow to condemn. Their inborn and unquenchable love of justice and fair-play operates as an effective curb upon their impulses. Their strong sense of gratitude likewise makes them prone to look with leniency upon the shortcomings of those who have rendered faithful service to the public. It is, on the other hand, hard to believe that Sir William Preece has been guilty of mere wanton fault finding, and it is still harder to conceive that he should allow himself to give utterance to a hasty censure. Regard for his own professional reputation would, presumably, have restrained him from hazarding opinions formed without a due and accurate knowledge of all the facts. Taking all these circumstances into account, it is but natural that his strictures should hate evoked a feeling of anxiety. Nothing will allay the uneasiness of the public but a clear and conclusive refutation of his charges of neglect, pronounced by experts of equal eminence and independence, and to this end a committee of investigation should be forthwith appointed whose standing and impartiality could not reasonably be challenged.
A delayed telegram from Baku shows that the bloodshed was due to rigorous repression by the military. (Reuter.)

Alarming reports on the condition in the Caucasus, and especially at Batum and Baku, have reached here. Communication with the district has been severed. No details have been received, but the reports agree there has been much bloodshed. (Reuter.)
Owing to the railway strikes, Poland is cut off from Germany and Austria. The terminus of the railway from Vienna to Warsaw is occupied by troops. (Reuter.)
Fresh strikes are constantly breaking out in all parts of Russia. The railway strike is spreading widely. (Reuter.)
Serious strike riots took place today here. The police were compelled to release the prisoners. The troops fired on the mob. The casualties are unknown. (Reuter)

div.head:
FUNERAL OF GRAND DUKE
MARKED WITH GREAT POMP

div.p: The funeral of the Grand Duke Sergius took place to-day. It was marked with great pomp, but the ceremony was entirely confined to the precincts of the Kremlin and nothing was visible to the public. The latter, nevertheless, thronged in the vicinity, where strong forces of troops had been posted. The Tsar and his family, the Ambassadors, and the Court were present at a requiem service at Tsarskoe Selo.

div.head:
NORTH SEA ENQUIRY
RUSSIAN DIPLOMATIC VICTORY.

div.p: The papers are generally surprised and dis­appointed at the finding of the North Sea Commission, which is described as a diplomatic victory for Russia. (Reuter)

The Commission's report has been signed to-day. It endorses the British standpoint in certain respects and considers that the firing was continued too long. Admiral Rodjestvensky ought to have informed the British authorities. (Reuter.)
It has been decided to issue a fourth do­mestic 6% loan of 100,000,000 yen at a price of 90 and redeemable in 7 years. (R.)
General Gripenberg has received orders to return to Manchuria. (Havas.)

Chamber of Deputies.—The Minister of Marine announced a proposed new naval pro­gramme, including the construction of 24 large warships, involving an annual expendi­ture of £4,750,000 sterling till 1917. Two naval bases could be established in Indo-China. A second dock at Saigon was essential. (R.)
The Chamber of Deputies has asked Mr. Thomson, Minister of Marine, to present his programme of naval building. (Havas.)
In succession to Sir J. A. Willox, who has resigned, Mr. Banner, Conservative, polled 3,854 votes against Mr. Aggs, Liberal, 2,543.
The boring of the Simplon Tunnel has been effected. (Havas.)
The Legislative Council will meet on Saturday.
The Annual Fancy Dress Ball will take place at the Savoy Hotel on Tuesday, March 14.
A Coptic Literary Society has been formed at Cairo and L.E. 400 has been subscribed to start it.

div.head: Standard Life Assurance Company.—
div.p: The Hon. A. J. Davey has joined the local board of this company.

div.head: Khedivial Agricultural Society. —
div.p: At yesterday afternoon's meeting of the society the annual report and the accounts for 1904 were submitted and approved.
"The Mikado," Gilbert and Sullivan's favorite opera, will shortly be staged at the Verdi Theatre, Cairo, the stage properties and costumes having now arrived from Europe.

div.head: The "Mahroussa."—
div.p: Nine officers and 133 of the crew, belonging to H.H. the Khedive s yacht "Mahroussa," landed at Port Said yes­terday from the Anchor liner "Circassia."

div.head: Fatal Accident.—
div.p: A native was killed by a train this morning on the Mariout line. The corpse was conveyed to the Government Hos­pital at Alexandria at midday for the post­mortem examination.

div.head: The Cretan Murder.—
div.p: The trial of Menegakis will take place next May, before the Hellenic Assize Court at Alexandria. The enquiry into the circumstances of the tragedy is still proceeding at the Hellenic Consulate at Alexandria.

Suez Canal.—9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 20th inst., 5 of which were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 1 French, 1 Norwegian. The day's receipts were frs. 253,802.16. The total receipts from the 1st inst. amounted to frs. 6,002,639.68.

div.head: White Star Line.—
div.p: Messrs. John Ross & Co., agents for the White Star Line at Alex­andria, inform us that the time occupied in the passage of the steamers of that line between Alexandria and Naples is under three days, and not four days, as has been stated.

The Cotton Worm.,—A useful little pamphlet dealing with preventive measures against the cotton worm has been written by Moussa Ghareb Bey, director of the Wady Tumulat estate in the Public Works Department. The pamphlet is published in French and Arabic.

div.head: The New Quay.—
div.p: On page 4 of to-day's issue we publish the second instalment of the Alexandria Municipality s important scheme of regulations for the sale of the quay estates, which has been drawn up by the Financial and Legal Departments of the Municipality.

The "Tailor and Cutter" reached its 2,000th issue on February 2, and the number for that date is an interesting one, as it con­tains plates giving examples of the varia­tions in style of dress during the period ofits existence, from the first plate of April 18,

div.head: Bishop Blyth's Visit.—
div.p: Owing to unforeseen circumstances, Bishop Blyth, the Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem and the Last, will arrive in Egypt a week later than was originally intended. As at present arranged, the Bishop will preach at All Saints,' Cairo, on March 19, and at St. Mark's, Alexandria, on March 26.

div.head: Sanatorium for Abbassieh.—
div.p: The Government has received an application from two capitalists for the cession of 25 square kilo­metres at L.E. 1 per feddan in the desert at Abbassieh in order to construct a sanatorium. A sixth of the site will be taken up by build­ings and the rest laid out in gardens, etc.

The Alhambra "Revue."—The Alexandria City Police have asked to be shown the manu­script of the forthcoming revue at the Alhambra Theatre, "Alexandrie en Baisse," but they were refused. Great efforts are being made to suppress all allusions to the recent scandal in which a well-known pasha of Alexandria is concerned.

The Fancy Dress Ball given by the Cairo French Benevolent Society will be held this evening under the patronage of M. de l: Bouliniére. The ball-room improvised by the committee in the Esbekieh Gardens is a triumph of skilful construction. Room has been found for 88 boxes in two tiers, in the ball-room itself there are two kiosks for the band and the orchestra, and the area of the floor, 35 metres by 15, should prevent any overcrowding. The whole structure will be lit by electricity, and the scene will be very brilliant

div.head: INSPECTION AT ABBASSIEH
div.p: H. R. H. the Inspector-General of the Forces inspected the troops at Abbassieh this morn­ing. The troops inspected were the 56th Bat­tery, R.F.A., 4th Mountain Battery, R.G.A., Mounted Infantry training company, and the Military Mounted Police.
The Duke and Duchess of Connaught visited the Museum of Arab Art on Wednesday after­noon. They are expected to honor to-day's races with their presence.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive visited his estates at Ismailia yesterday and returned to Abdeen this morning. He attended midday prayer at the Mosque of El Imam El Shafei.

div.head: THE LATE GRAND DUKE SERGIUS
div.p: At 9 a.m. to-morrow, a requiem mass will be celebrated at the Greek-Orthodox Cathedral of Hamzawi, Cairo, for the repose of the soul of the Grand Duke Sergius, uncle of the Tsar. A funeral service will follow the mass at 10.30 a.m.
M. Maximoff and the whole of the staff of the Imperial Russian Agency and Consulate will be present.

div.head: RECEPTION AT BRITISH AGENCY
div.p: A reception will be held at the British Agency, Cairo, to-night, to which are invited the various diplomatic agents in Cairo, the three British Under-Secretaries of State, the Headquarters Staff of the Army of Occupation, with the principal British officers of the Egyp­tian Army now in Cairo, and the commanders of units of the British and Egyptian forces, with the British heads of departments.

div.head: THE RAILWAY REPORT
div.p: The decision arrived at recently to publish only portions of the report of the Railway Commissioners has been altered, and the report will shortly be published in full.

div.head: CAIRO LIBEL CASE
div.p: A criminal libel case of some local interest came before the Supreme Consular Court, Cairo, this morning. Mr. J. W. Congdon, a well-known British resident in the Capital, brought an action against Mr. Houghton for a 'false, ma­licious, defamatory, and libellous article" writ­ten by him and published in the "Egyptian Graphic" on the 15th. The plaintiff was represented by Mr. D. G. Cuppa, barrister-at- law. Mr. William Houghton, who was described as a journalist, was not represented by coun­sel. In the opinion of the judge, however, the case did not call for criminal proceedings and be therefore ruled the dismissal of criminal proceedings, leaving it to the prosecutor to take civil proceedings if he cared to. The case was then dismissed. There is an essential difference between civil and criminal libel. The former is considered simply as an injury to the indivi­dual, the latter as an injury to the State.

div.head: GHEZIREH CASINO
div.p: The ball held at the Ghezireh Casino yesterday evening was a most brilliant success. In the decorations palms and flowers were extensively employed, and, together with a profusion of uniforms and pretty toilettes, made a very charming sight. A large number of the officers of the Army of Occupation were present, with many well-know a visitors and residents, and we noticed a very large foreign element. The floor was very good, and the music was in excellent time. The last of the dancers did not leave until an early hour this morning. We congratulate the authorities of Ghezireh Palace Hotel, who were responsible lor the management of the ball, on the great success which attended their efforts.

div.head: NOTES FROM MENA
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Vere Alston have left Mena House after a stay of over three months. Mr. Alston has, we are pleased to hear, com­pletely recovered from his severe illness.

Among the visitors who have lately arrived at Mena House are Major the Hon. E. B. and Mrs. Bourke, Hon. Gerald Fitz-Gerald and Lady Nesta Fitz-Gerald, Capt. Rhodes (younger brother of the late Cecil Rhodes), Countess Cara Armin, Countess Banffy, Count and Countess de Greneville, Herr von Pilgrim- Baltazzi, etc.
Among those shortly expected are Lady Gay, Lady Jane Tetter and Mrs. Tetter, and Sir Henry Hoare.
The next dance at Mena House will take place on Wednesday, March 1, at 9.30 p.m. There will be a special tramway service for the occasion, as usual.
The management of the hotel are putting up tents in the desert, as was done last year, for visitors wishing to sleep out in tents and board at the hotel. The hire of these tents is very moderate.

div.head: MR. ALDERSON'S RESIGNATION
div.p: I noticed in the papers of yesterday a para­graph stating that my sending in an excuse for not attending the meeting of the Municipal Commission of the 22nd inst. means that I withdraw my resignation. This is not the case. The documents and "ordre du jour" relating to the above meeting having been sent me, and not having as yet received any reply from the Municipality re my letter of resignation, I thought it only civil to inform them that I had a call to Cairo; therefore in any case could not have attended.— Geo. B. Alderson.

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
div.p: TERRAINS DÉS QUAIS
Projet de reglement pour la vente des terrains de la Municipalité d'Alexandrie, arrete par les Co­mites des Finances et du Con­tentieux.
1er.— Les terrains de la Municipalité seront catalogués, et un prix dévaluation sera fixé pour chaque lot, par la Commission Muni­cipale, sur la proposition du Comité d'estimation.
Dans aucun cas, la vente de ces terrains ne pourra être faite à un prix inférieur à celui fixé par l'évaluation.
Ces prix pourront être révisés dans le pre­mier trimestre de chaque année.
Art. 2.— Les ventes s'effectueront par voie d'enchères ou de soumissions.
Toutefois, si, avant la mise en vente, le Gouvernement veut dans un but d'utilité géné­rale, acquérir un ou plusieurs lots, ils lui seront cédés au prix d'estimation du catalogue.
La cession pourra également se faire par voie d'échange.
Art. 3.— Les terrains seront vendus tels qu'ils se comportent, avec toutes leurs servitu­des actives et passives, et sans qu'aucun re­cours puisse être exercé, de ce chef, contre la Municipalité.

Art. 4.— Le prix d'achat sera payable : Vingt cinq pour cent, comptant et le solde en dix années, par fractions égales, avec intérêts à quatre pour cent par an, payables annuellement, à partir du 5e jour qui suivra l'adjudi­cation.

Art. 5.— La mise en vente sera portée à la connaissance du public, au moyen d'avis dans le Journal Officiel, et dans trois journaux d'Alexandrie, au moins. Ces avis seront égale­ment affichés à la Municipalité, au Gouvernorat et à la Bourse Khédiviale ; ils désigneront les lots mis en vente ; ils indiqueront leur numéro au catalogue et leur contenance, ainsi que leur mise à prix, forme de la mise en adjudication, et le jour et l'heure de la séance.
Art. 6.— Aucune personne ne pourra vala­blement concourir aux enchères sans avoir effectué au préalable, le versement d'un dépôt du 10 % de la mise à prix.
Ce dépôt ne portera aucun intérêt. Il pourra être versé jusqu'au moment de l'ouverture des enchères ou des soumissions.
Les enchérisseurs dont les offres n'auront pas été agréées, pourront retirer leurs dépôts dès le lendemain.

Art 7. — Toute offre implique, de plein droit, déclaration de connaissance du lot mis en vente, ainsi qu'adhésion au cahier des charges et aux dispositions du présent règlement. Elle devra être pure et simple ; l'offre qui exprime­rait une modalité serait considérée comme non avenue. Elle devra contenir une élection de domicile à Alexandrie, si l'enchérisseur ou sou­missionnaire n'y demeure pas. De même, l'en­chérisseur devenu adjudicataire, devra, s'il cesse de demeurer à Alexandrie, faire et com­muniquer une élection de domicile en la dite ville. Faute de ce faire et dans ces deux hypo­thèses, toute notification sera, de pacte express, valablement faite par la Municipalité, au greffe du tribunal mixte ou indigène d'Alex­andrie, selon la nationalité.

Art. 8.— Les acheteurs en commun, quelle que soit la quote-part de chacun d'eux, seront solidaires les uns des autres pour l'exécution de toutes les conditions de l'adjudication, et considérés comme une seule partie contrac­tante.

Art. 9.— Les séances d'enchères ou d'ou­verture des soumissions auront lieu à la Muni­cipalité au plus tôt trente jours après la publication des avis. Elles seront présidées par le Vice-Président de la Commission, eu par le Conseiller qui le suppléera, assisté de l'Admi­nistrateur. L'adjudication sera faite au profit du plus offrant ; au cas de plusieurs offres égales, il sera tiré au sort, séance tenante.
Art. 10.— Dans les cinq jours qui suivront, l'adjudicataire devra payer lé solde du premier terme, et consigner le montant des droits de transcription.
Art. 11.-- Il devra être passé acte authentique des ventes, aux Irais de l'acheteur, dans le mois qui suivra le paiement du solde du 1er terme.

Les actes de vente ne pourront être dressés qu'au nom de l'adjudicataire, à moins que celui-ci n'ait déclaré, au moment de la vente, qu'il agissait en qualité de mandataire et qu'il n'ait, en justifiant de cette qualité, fait connaitre le nom de son mandant, dont mention sera faite au procès-verbal d'adjudication.

Art. 12.—Les paiements doivent être faits à la Caisse Municipale où les fonds sont porta­bles. Au cas de non paiement exact et intégral du premier terme, dans le délai fixé à l'art 10, la Municipalité aura la faculté soit de considérer la vente comme définitivement résolue de plein droit, sans besoin de mise en demeure, et, en ce cas, le cautionnement deviendra la pro­priété de la Commission, à titre d'indemnité de résiliation d'après la présente clause pénale, soit de remettre le lot en vente, dans les mêmes formes, aux frais et pour compte de l'adjudica­taire, qui sera tenu de la différence d'avec le prix net d'adjudication et ses intérêts à quatre pour cent sur la totalité de ce prix, soit enfin, de poursuivre par les voies ordinaires l'exécu­tion des obligations de l'acheteur et, en ce der­nier cas, l'intérêt de retard courra de plein droit à sa charge au taux de cinq pour cent.

Au cas de retard dans le paiement de l'un des dix termes subséquents, dont le montant est également portable à la Caisse Municipale, l'intérêt de retard courra également de plein droit à cinq pour cent, sans préjudice des droits fixés par les art. 413 du Code Civil, et 334 du Code Civil Indigène.
Art. 13.— L'Administration consignera le terrain à l'adjudicataire dès le paiement du solde du 1er terme. Les bornes seront aux frais des acheteurs.
Les procès-verbaux de consignation seront faits en double, et seront signés par les

adjudicataires ou leurs représentants, ainsi que par les agents chargés de la consignation. Au cas où l'adjudicataire ne se présenterait pas, quoi­que invité, pour recevoir la consignation, le procès-verbal signé par les seuls agents de l'Administration vaudra délivrance définitive et consignation.

Art. 14.— Si le mesurage fait lors de la con­signation fait ressortir une différence de conte­nance, soit en plus, soit en moins, avec la con­tenance indiquée sur l'avis de mise en vente, le prix de vente sera augmenté ou diminué proportionnellement à la différence en plus ou en moins.
(à suivre)

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd' hui à midi et demie)

Aujourd'hui les valeurs égyptiennes sont en baisse à Londres. La Banque Nationale, entre autres, perd 1 livre en tombant d'un seul coup de 28 1/4 à 27 1/4. La raison de cette dégringolade provient d'importants ordres de ventes transmis du Caire à Londres. On veut,parait-il, se défaire ici des titres égyptiens pour em­ployer ses capitaux en fonds d'Ètat Étrangers qui vont sûrement hausser en prévision de la paix.

Aussi toute la cote est-elle en baisse sur notre place. Pour ne citer que les principales valeurs, la Banque Nationale tombe à 27 3/16, l'Agricole à 11 1/4, la Daïra à 25 1/16, la Delta Light à 14 3/8...
On croit que le marché reprendra bientôt.

div.head: NOTICE TO OUR READERS
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" arribes in Cairo every night at 7:30 p.m. and the house-to-house delivery of the paper to our subscribers begins at 9 p.m. All com[laints as to delay in receiving the "Gazette" should be addressed to the Local Director of the Cairo Post Office. A number of complaints would be obviated if letter boxed were put up at the main entrances of subscribers' houses

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les tra- vaux d empierrement de la route de Siouf de- puis la station San Stefano a la rue El Ekbal.
Le cautionnement est fixé a LE. 70.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau de la Voirie oh il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h.a midi,les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous plî ca cheté a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Muni cipalité avant le 14 Mars 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le méme jour à 5h.p.m L'enveloppe devra porter, en outre la men- tion : "Sonmission ponr Empierrement de la Route de Siouf.
Le cautionnement qu le reçu d'une Banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Service de Comptabilité avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 14 mars à midi.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. Chataway Alexandrie, le 23 février 1905. 25484-3-3
